decision.reasoning:
<contrarian_case>
The case for a New England Patriots victory rests on three core pillars: an elite passing offense, a defense peaking at the perfect moment, and the potential for the Seahawks' offense to regress to its mean.

First, the Patriots' offense is statistically elite where it matters most. They rank 2nd in Pass DVOA and 1st in EPA/Dropback. This isn't just a good offense; it's the most efficient passing attack in the league. Even against the Seahawks' top-ranked defense, a truly elite offense can dictate the terms of the game and find ways to score. The news that quarterback Drake Maye is a full participant in practice and his shoulder is not a concern is critical; a healthy Maye helming this passing attack gives New England a significant advantage and a clear path to putting up points.

Second, while the Patriots' defense had "ordinary" regular-season metrics, their postseason performance has been formidable. They have allowed only six explosive plays through three playoff games, demonstrating a clear schematic or performance-level improvement. This suggests they are a team hitting its stride. The narrative that they only faced "compromised" offenses can be flipped: they dominated the opponents they were supposed to, which is the mark of a championship-caliber team seizing momentum.

Finally, the Seahawks' recent success may be built on an unsustainable offensive performance. Their NFC Championship win was largely credited to quarterback Sam Darnold playing "one of the best games of his life." Statistically, it is far more likely for a player to regress toward their career average than to repeat a peak performance, especially on the Super Bowl stage. If Darnold returns to his typical, more mistake-prone form, the Seahawks' offense will sputter against a disciplined and hot Patriots defense.

In essence, the Patriots have the most potent single unit in this matchup (their passing offense) and a defense that is playing its best football of the year, while their opponents may be overly reliant on a volatile and likely unrepeatable offensive explosion.
</contrarian_case>

<reasoning>
I have seriously considered the contrarian case, and it has merit, particularly the strength-on-strength matchup of the Patriots' elite passing offense vs. the Seahawks' elite defense. The potential for Sam Darnold to regress is also a very real statistical probability.

However, the weight of the data still points firmly toward the Seahawks. The most significant piece of evidence is the professional betting market. Vegas oddsmakers, who have the most accurate prediction models, have the Seahawks as a 4.5-point favorite, with a moneyline (-230) that implies a ~65-66% win probability (after removing the vig). The current market price of 54.3% represents a massive discount to the professional consensus. As a statistics-focused forecaster, ignoring such a

results.title: Patriots hold first official practice of Super Bowl week, Drake Maye "feeling great" - CBS Boston
results.snippet: The New England Patriots officially practiced for the first time on Wednesday ahead of Super Bowl LX against the Seattle Seahawks. Among those on the field at Stanford University was quarterback Drake Maye, who was limited all of last week with a shoulder injury and missed Friday's session with an illness.

results.title: Super Bowl LX injury report: Updates on Drake Maye's right shoulder, Sam Darnold's oblique, more - CBS Sports
results.snippet: Seahawks: Seattle had perfect attendance at practice, but did have several players limited: Quarterback Sam Darnold (oblique), offensive tackle Charles Cross (foot), safety Nick Emmanwori (ankle), offensive tackle Josh Jones (ankle, knee), linebacker Demarcus Lawrence (rest), fullback Robbie Ouzts (neck), receiver Jaxon Smith-Njigba (rest), and defensive end Leonard Williams (rest). Patriots: Linebacker Robert Spillane (ankle) did not practice on Wednesday due to an ankle injury. However, he did tell the Boston Herald earlier in the day that he's "100% confident" that he'll be able to play in Super Bowl LX. Meanwhile, linebacker Harold Landry (knee) and offensive tackle Thayer Munford Jr. were both limited with knee injuries. Maybe the most important development on the injury front for New England comes at quarterback as the team listed Drake Maye (right shoulder) as a full participant.

decision.reasoning:
As a statistics-focused forecaster, the health of a starting quarterback is a primary variable in any predictive model. Any uncertainty around Drake Maye's availability or effectiveness would have justifiably increased the Seahawks' probability of winning. The latest news completely removes that uncertainty. With Maye confirmed at 100%, the Patriots' offensive potential is at its maximum expected value.

This news is unequivocally negative for the Seahawks' chances. The market is currently at 20.2% for a Seattle win, which already reflects the Patriots as heavy favorites. However, this price may have been factoring in some small percentage chance of Maye being limited. The complete removal of that doubt should, logically, push the Seahawks' probability even lower. My current heavy-long position on Seattle is now at greater risk, and I must adjust my holdings to reflect this new, negative data point for my side.
decision.raw:
<new_information>
The most significant piece of new, material information is the final confirmation of the health status of New England Patriots quarterback Drake Maye. After being limited in practice earlier in the week with a shoulder injury and missing a session with an illness, multiple reports now confirm he was a "full participant" in the final practices and is "set to start" with no limitations. Patriots staff have stated he is "feeling great."

Other minor news includes the Seahawks adding two running backs to their active roster, but the context and impact of this move are unclear and likely minimal. The weather forecast is for ideal conditions (mid-60s, clear), which is a non-factor.
</new_information>
